While safeguards will be put in place for people returning from some countries to prevent coronavirus re-entering Wales, we still advise you to only travel abroad for essential purposes.

We will keep you updated on the traffic light system and any further announcements.

You'll need to check entry requirements before you go.

From 24 May, “vaccine passports” will be available for fully vaccinated people but only for those who urgently need it.

Please don't request this from your GP or vaccine centre - they're busy vaccinating.

International travel from Wales can resume on Monday – we’re advising you only do so for essential reasons.

A traffic light system, in line with England and Scotland, will be introduced.

Travel will be allowed to “green list” destinations with no need to quarantine on return. https://t.co/BreTkoyVBA

Read more about the move to level 2 here 👇
https://t.co/PzHfdhsY2h

@Happily_Insane_ People in an existing support bubble can therefore join with one more household to form an extended household. Diolch

@Happily_Insane_ Good Afternoon. The rules in Wales change on 3 May to allow any two households to form an extended household or ‘bubble’. A third household can join an extended household in limited circumstances, including where an adult lives alone or is a single parent.
@SjFrostie People in an existing support bubble can therefore join with one more household to form an extended household. Diolch

@SjFrostie Good Afternoon. The rules in Wales change on 3 May to allow any two households to form an extended household or ‘bubble’. A third household can join an extended household in limited circumstances, including where an adult lives alone or is a single parent.

@rich_nosworthy A third household can join an extended household in limited circumstances, including where an adult lives alone or is a single parent. People in an existing support bubble can therefore join with one more household to form an extended household. Diolch
@rich_nosworthy Good Afternoon. Sorry for the delay in responding. The rules in Wales change on 3 May to allow any two households to form an extended household or ‘bubble’.

We have 45 mass vaccination centres operating or due to open shortly. These will be offering the Pfizer vaccine.

Around 90% of them were open over the weekend.

As supply increases, more and more will be open for longer and seven days per week.

We have more than 100 GP practices delivering vaccines.
That will rise to 250 by end of January.

GP-led clinics will be open evenings and weekends as vaccine supply increases.

Every dose wasted is a vaccine which cannot be given to someone in Wales.

Less than 1% of the vaccines have not been used.

This is way below the wastage rates normally seen for vaccines.

We’re not holding back any vaccines.

The Pfizer vaccine must be stored at ultra-low temperatures – at -70°C – in two special centres. 

Once removed the vaccine lasts five days.

We’re on course to offer vaccines to all frontline health and care workers, everyone living and working in care homes, and everyone over 70 by mid-February.

By spring, we'll vaccinate all over 50s and everyone at risk due to a health condition.

A huge amount of work is going on to make vaccines available as quickly and safely as possible.

We're mobilising doctors, nurses, military personnel, primary care practitioners, dentists and optometrists.

Volunteers are also being trained to help us deliver this programme.

AN UPDATE ON CORONAVIRUS VACCINES IN WALES 👇 (a thread)

As of 10pm last night, 151,737 people have had their first dose of the vaccine – 5% of the population.

We have mass vaccination centres, hospitals and GPs delivering vaccines.

More people are being vaccinated every week.
